label: chapter_5_Files_.pdf
title: Files and Streams Fundamentals & The File Class & Sequential-Access Text Files & Updating Sequential-Access Files & Object Serialization & Additional java.io Classes & Data and Buffered Streams & Character-Based and Memory-Based Streams & JFileChooser and File Selection

questions.text: How does Java view a file in its most basic architectural form?

choices.label: As a structured database of records
choices.text: As a structured database of records

choices.label: As a sequential stream of bytes
choices.text: As a sequential stream of bytes

choices.label: As a collection of objects organized in a tree
choices.text: As a collection of objects organized in a tree

choices.label: As a random-access array of integers
choices.text: As a random-access array of integers

questions.explanation: Java views each file as a sequential stream of bytes, allowing programs to process data without needing to know the specific underlying platform representation.

questions.text: What is the difference between how a byte-based stream and a character-based stream would store the numeric value 5?

choices.label: Byte-based stores it as 101; Character-based stores it as the Unicode value for '5' (53).
choices.text: Byte-based stores it as 101; Character-based stores it as the Unicode value for '5' (53).

choices.label: Byte-based stores it as a String; Character-based stores it as a literal 5.
choices.text: Byte-based stores it as a String; Character-based stores it as a literal 5.

choices.label: Both store it as 101, but character-based streams add a null terminator.
choices.text: Both store it as 101, but character-based streams add a null terminator.

choices.label: Character-based streams cannot store numeric values.
choices.text: Character-based streams cannot store numeric values.

questions.explanation: Byte-based streams store data in binary format (5 = 101), while character-based streams store the character representation (Unicode '5' is decimal 53).

questions.text: Which object is used by a Java program to output character-based error messages to the screen by default?
questions.explanation: System.err is the standard error stream object, normally used for outputting character-based error messages to the screen.

questions.text: Which classes serve as the base for byte-based input and output in the `java.io` package?
questions.explanation: FileInputStream and FileOutputStream inherit from the abstract classes InputStream and OutputStream, which handle byte-based I/O.

questions.text: What happens to the data stored in a variable when a local variable goes out of scope or the program terminates?

choices.label: It is automatically saved to a backup file.
choices.text: It is automatically saved to a backup file.

choices.label: It is moved to secondary storage.
choices.text: It is moved to secondary storage.

questions.explanation: Data in variables is temporary. For long-term (persistent) retention, data must be stored in files on secondary storage devices.

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding objects of class `java.io.File`?

choices.label: They are used to read and write bytes to a file.
choices.text: They are used to read and write bytes to a file.

choices.label: They can be used to retrieve information such as file size and modification time.
choices.text: They can be used to retrieve information such as file size and modification time.

choices.label: They automatically open a file for processing upon instantiation.
choices.text: They automatically open a file for processing upon instantiation.

choices.label: They are only used for text files, not binary files.
choices.text: They are only used for text files, not binary files.

questions.explanation: File objects provide information about files and directories (like length and modification date) but do not provide file-processing (read/write) capabilities themselves.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `File.separator` constant?

choices.label: To separate different files in a comma-separated list.
choices.text: To separate different files in a comma-separated list.

choices.label: To provide the platform-specific character used to separate directories in a path.
choices.text: To provide the platform-specific character used to separate directories in a path.

choices.label: To delete files from a directory.
choices.text: To delete files from a directory.

choices.label: To act as an end-of-file marker.
choices.text: To act as an end-of-file marker.

questions.explanation: Different operating systems use different characters (\ for Windows, / for Unix). File.separator returns the correct character for the local system.

questions.text: What does the `File` method `list()` return if the object represents a directory?

choices.label: A long value representing total bytes.
choices.text: A long value representing total bytes.

choices.label: A boolean indicating if the directory is empty.
choices.text: A boolean indicating if the directory is empty.

choices.label: An array of Strings representing the directory's contents.
choices.text: An array of Strings representing the directory's contents.

questions.explanation: The list() method returns a String array containing the names of the files and directories within the directory represented by the File object.

questions.text: Which `File` method would you use to determine if a specific path exists on the disk?
questions.explanation: The exists() method returns true if the file or directory represented by the File object actually exists on the disk.
The getParent() method returns a String representing the parent directory of the file or directory specified in the File object.

questions.text: What happens when you use the `Formatter` constructor `new Formatter("clients.txt")` if the file 'clients.txt' already exists?

choices.label: New data is appended to the end of the file.
choices.text: New data is appended to the end of the file.

choices.label: The constructor fails and returns null.
choices.text: The constructor fails and returns null.

questions.explanation: When an existing file is opened with class Formatter, its contents are truncated, meaning all existing data in the file is deleted.

questions.text: Which exception is thrown if a program tries to write to a file using a `Formatter` object that has already been closed?
questions.explanation: As noted in the text, if the Formatter object is closed and a format operation is attempted, a FormatterClosedException is thrown.

questions.text: To signal the end of input (EOF) when running a console-based Java program on Windows, which key combination should be used?
questions.explanation: On Windows systems, the end-of-file indicator is <Ctrl> z. On Unix/Linux/Mac systems, it is <Ctrl> d.

questions.text: In the provided example of `ReadTextFile.java`, what object is passed to the `Scanner` constructor to allow it to read from a file?

choices.label: A String containing the file path.
choices.text: A String containing the file path.

questions.explanation: To read from a file, the Scanner is instantiated with a File object, e.g., `new Scanner(new File("clients.txt"))`.

questions.text: What does the `%n` format specifier represent in a format control string?
questions.explanation: %n outputs a platform-specific line separator, ensuring the file is readable in native text editors (like Notepad vs. vi).

questions.text: Which exception is thrown by the `Scanner` method `nextInt` if the data being read is not a valid integer?
questions.explanation: If the information in the file is not properly formed (e.g., a String is found where an int is expected), a NoSuchElementException occurs.

questions.text: How can a program reposition a `Scanner` to the beginning of a file to read it again?

choices.label: Call the reset() method on the Scanner object.
choices.text: Call the reset() method on the Scanner object.

choices.label: The program must close the file and reopen it.
choices.text: The program must close the file and reopen it.

questions.explanation: Class Scanner does not allow repositioning to the beginning of a file. To read it again, the program must close and reopen the file.

questions.text: What does the method `hasNext()` return when the end-of-file marker is reached?
questions.explanation: Method hasNext returns false when the end-of-file marker is reached.

questions.text: Which exception occurs if a `Scanner` method is called after the `Scanner` has been closed?
questions.explanation: If the Scanner was closed before data was input, an IllegalStateException occurs.

questions.text: In the provided credit-inquiry case study, how are credit balances defined?
questions.explanation: According to the text, a credit balance is a negative amount, and a debit balance is a positive amount.

questions.text: Why is it generally avoided to update a record in place within a sequential text file?

choices.label: Text files are read-only by default.
choices.text: Text files are read-only by default.

choices.label: Java does not support writing to text files.
choices.text: Java does not support writing to text files.

choices.label: Because fields can vary in size, a longer new record might overwrite the start of the next record.
choices.text: Because fields can vary in size, a longer new record might overwrite the start of the next record.

questions.explanation: Fields in text files vary in size. If a new record is larger than the original, it will overwrite the data belonging to the next sequential record.

questions.text: What is the standard procedure for updating records in a sequential-access file?

choices.label: Rewrite the entire file, copying old records and inserting new ones.
choices.text: Rewrite the entire file, copying old records and inserting new ones.

choices.label: Delete the file and prompt the user to re-enter all data.
choices.text: Delete the file and prompt the user to re-enter all data.

choices.label: Append the updated record to the end of the file and leave the old one.
choices.text: Append the updated record to the end of the file and leave the old one.

questions.explanation: To make a change, records before the target are copied to a new file, the updated record is written, and the subsequent records are copied over.

questions.text: What is required for a class to be used with `ObjectOutputStream` for serialization?

choices.label: It must override the toString() method.
choices.text: It must override the toString() method.

choices.label: It must implement the Serializable interface.
choices.text: It must implement the Serializable interface.

choices.label: It must be declared as static.
choices.text: It must be declared as static.

choices.label: It must inherit from class File.
choices.text: It must inherit from class File.

questions.explanation: An ObjectOutputStream will not output an object unless it implements the Serializable interface.

questions.text: Which interface is known as a 'tagging interface' because it contains no methods?
questions.explanation: Interface Serializable is a tagging interface because it does not contain methods; it simply 'tags' a class as being serializable.

questions.text: Which keyword is used to indicate that a specific instance variable should be ignored during the serialization process?
questions.explanation: Non-Serializable instance variables must be declared transient to indicate that they should be ignored during serialization.

questions.text: What is 'wrapping' in the context of Java I/O streams?

choices.label: Encoding data into a ZIP format.
choices.text: Encoding data into a ZIP format.

choices.label: Initializing a stream object using another stream object in the constructor.
choices.text: Initializing a stream object using another stream object in the constructor.

choices.label: Hiding a private stream inside a public class.
choices.text: Hiding a private stream inside a public class.

choices.label: Closing a stream automatically using a try-with-resources block.
choices.text: Closing a stream automatically using a try-with-resources block.

questions.explanation: Wrapping occurs when a new stream object is created by passing another stream object as a constructor argument, such as wrapping a FileInputStream in an ObjectInputStream.

questions.text: Which exception is used to signal that the end of a file has been reached during an `ObjectInputStream` read operation?
questions.explanation: Method readObject throws an EOFException if an attempt is made to read beyond the end of the file.

questions.text: Which classes are used to establish synchronized communication channels between two threads?
questions.explanation: Java provides PipedOutputStream and PipedInputStream to establish pipes (communication channels) between two threads.

questions.text: What type of objects are `System.out` and `System.err`?
questions.explanation: System.out and System.err are concrete examples of PrintStream objects, which perform text output to a stream.

questions.text: Which interface describes methods for reading primitive types from an input stream and is implemented by both `DataInputStream` and `RandomAccessFile`?
questions.explanation: Interface DataInput describes methods like readInt and readDouble for reading primitive types. It is implemented by DataInputStream and RandomAccessFile.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of using `BufferedOutputStream`?

choices.label: To convert byte data into Unicode characters
choices.text: To convert byte data into Unicode characters

choices.label: To ensure data is written to the disk immediately after every write statement
choices.text: To ensure data is written to the disk immediately after every write statement

choices.label: To reduce the number of physical output operations by using a memory buffer
choices.text: To reduce the number of physical output operations by using a memory buffer

choices.label: To encrypt data before it is sent to the physical device
choices.text: To encrypt data before it is sent to the physical device

questions.explanation: Buffering is a performance-enhancement technique that reduces physical I/O operations by storing data in a memory buffer and performing physical transfers in larger blocks.

questions.text: Which method should be called to force a partially filled buffer to be written to the output device?
questions.explanation: The flush method is used to force out any data remaining in a BufferedOutputStream's memory buffer to the physical device.

questions.text: In the context of buffered I/O, what is a 'logical input operation'?

choices.label: The act of reading a large block of data from a disk into a buffer
choices.text: The act of reading a large block of data from a disk into a buffer

choices.label: A request from a program to take a chunk of data from the memory buffer
choices.text: A request from a program to take a chunk of data from the memory buffer

choices.label: The validation routine performed on raw bytes
choices.text: The validation routine performed on raw bytes

choices.label: The conversion of binary data into human-readable text
choices.text: The conversion of binary data into human-readable text

questions.explanation: A logical input operation occurs when the program requests data and it is retrieved from the buffer rather than the physical device.

questions.text: Which of these classes is a subclass of `FilterOutputStream`?
questions.explanation: The text explicitly mentions that DataOutputStream is a subclass of FilterOutputStream.

questions.text: Which abstract classes serve as the base for Unicode character-based streams in Java?
questions.explanation: Reader and Writer are the abstract classes for two-byte, character-based (Unicode) streams.

questions.text: Which class can be used to convert an `InputStream` into a character-based `Reader`?
questions.explanation: Class InputStreamReader acts as a bridge, converting an InputStream (bytes) into a Reader (characters).

questions.text: What is the specific functionality provided by `LineNumberReader`?

choices.label: It sorts lines alphabetically as they are read
choices.text: It sorts lines alphabetically as they are read

choices.label: It limits the number of lines a program can read from a file
choices.text: It limits the number of lines a program can read from a file

choices.label: It keeps track of the number of lines read by monitoring newlines and carriage returns
choices.text: It keeps track of the number of lines read by monitoring newlines and carriage returns

choices.label: It automatically formats output to fit within a specific line length
choices.text: It automatically formats output to fit within a specific line length

questions.explanation: LineNumberReader is a subclass of BufferedReader that increments a line count based on newline, return, or carriage-return-line-feed combinations.

questions.text: Which class allows a program to logically concatenate several `InputStream` objects and treat them as a single continuous stream?
questions.explanation: SequenceInputStream logically concatenates several input streams into one.

questions.text: Which pair of classes is used for transferring character data between threads?
questions.explanation: PipedReader and PipedWriter implement piped-character streams specifically for transferring data between threads.

questions.text: Which `JFileChooser` constant should be used if the user needs to select either a single file or an entire directory?
questions.explanation: The constant FILES_AND_DIRECTORIES indicates that both files and directories can be selected in the dialog.

questions.text: What does it mean that a `JFileChooser` dialog is 'modal'?

choices.label: It can only be used once per program execution
choices.text: It can only be used once per program execution

choices.label: It does not allow interaction with other windows in the program until it is closed
choices.text: It does not allow interaction with other windows in the program until it is closed

choices.label: It can only display files of a specific 'mode' or extension
choices.text: It can only display files of a specific 'mode' or extension

choices.label: It automatically selects the most frequently used file
choices.text: It automatically selects the most frequently used file

questions.explanation: A modal dialog prevents the user from interacting with other parts of the application until the dialog is dismissed.

questions.text: Which method is called to display the `JFileChooser` dialog with an 'Open' button?
questions.explanation: The method showOpenDialog(Component parent) is used to display the dialog.

questions.text: How does a program determine if the user clicked the 'Cancel' button on a `JFileChooser`?

choices.label: By checking if the return value of the dialog is JFileChooser.CANCEL_OPTION
choices.text: By checking if the return value of the dialog is JFileChooser.CANCEL_OPTION

choices.label: By checking if the getSelectedFile() method returns null
choices.text: By checking if the getSelectedFile() method returns null

choices.label: By checking if the dialog's visibility is set to false
choices.text: By checking if the dialog's visibility is set to false

questions.explanation: The showOpenDialog method returns an integer; comparing this to JFileChooser.CANCEL_OPTION identifies if the user canceled the operation.

questions.text: Which method of `JFileChooser` retrieves the `File` object selected by the user?
questions.explanation: The getSelectedFile() method returns the File object representing the selection made by the user in the dialog.
